title: Addams Family production is huge success
story: ST Patrickrsquos Grammar School students once again enjoyed a phenomenally successful run in their recent production of The Addams Family.Under the direction of Siobhan OrsquoToole, Head of Drama, the performers received standing ovations after each show, which according an audience member would not have out of place in the West End of London.Pupils from every year group in the school were involved in the production and assumed major roles of responsibility, ranging from stage managers to set design.From start to finish, the show was pacy and slick, bursting with comedy and superb aesthetics. The principal cast performed like seasoned professionals, bringing the iconic characters to le with flair and panache.Eoin McGuinness and Ellen McGurnaghan were outstanding in their comic portrayals of Gomez and Morticia Addams, while Annie Haughey and Eoin Moore were superb as the sinister siblings, Wednesday and Pugsley.The hilariously embarrassing grandmother was played by Aisha Oladipupo, and Year  student Conaire Laverty brought endless laughs as the grunting Lurch. Conn Murnin, as Uncle Fester, was a particular audience favourite and his departure on a rocket to seek the love of his le mdash the Moon mdash was a highlight of the show.The ever present long dead Addams ancestors were a tight and focused chorus including a stunning range of costumes from cavemen to flappers. All-American family, the Beinekes, played by Malachy McGrady, Elisha Tumelty and Tomaacutes Harkinleft the audience in stitches as they struggled to deal with ways of the weird and wonderful Addams family. All ended happily ever after, however, as both families moved towards the darkness and embraced who they really were.Featuring an exceptional live orchestra led by Head of Music Celeste McEvoy and music teacher Ciara Coleman, and with magnicent set, costume, lighting and sound complementing the breathtaking musical and dramatic talent of these students, it really was a show not to be missed..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahich Post Office remains
story: RESIDENTS in Ballynahinch will continue to have access to a first class Post Office service in the New Year after all.Days after it was suggested that the current office in Lisburn Street would close temporarily on January , it was confirmed this week that there will be no break in service.The current postmistress will vacate her position on January  with M Retail Ltd taking over the service the following day.Mrs Donna Carlisle mdash who is the current postmistress mdash said everything will continue as normal in the New Year and that there will be no interruption to services.Rowallane councillor Billy Walker, who said last week that it was his understanding that the Ballynahinch Post Office was to close temporarily, is delighted that normal service is to continue.He said post offices are at the heart of communities and are used by a wide range of people, in particular the elderly, who enjoy the face-to-face contact with staff.ldquoBallynahinch is the districtrsquos third largest town and I am pleased that there will be no interruption to postal services, he continued.ldquoMany elderly people prefer to conduct their business at post offices rather than banks. The Post Office provides a vital service and the people of Ballynahinch will be delighted that this service is to remain in place, providing a wide range of services..prettyPhoto

title: Christmas cracker in store
story: KILLOUGH have every intention on rockinrsquo around the Christmas tree with the Bobby Dalzell Cup next Thursday night.Standing in the way of the Mill Field sidersquos celebrations are Ballynahinch Olympic Town, who also want their hands on the coveted trophy.The Yuletide showdown at Meadowvale is sure to be a Christmas cracker.Both sides know only one way to play and that is attack, attack, attack.Between them they scored  goals in the semi-finals and more are promised on Boxing Day.Killough, cup specialists over the past  years or so, know how to win big games.They have a cup mentality and leave nothing out on the pitch, reserving their best form for one-off encounters.In Colm Stranney at centre half they have a freak of nature.The guy is still going strongly at  years of age and he will be playing in his th final for the club mdash winning six and losing four.He is the glue that keeps Killough bonded together.Sound in the air, deceptively quick on the ground and absolutely fearless in the tackle, Stranney really is a man for all seasons.He is the sort of player who gets on with the job without histrionics or fuss and he even has time to nurture young talent when they break into the first team squad.He certainly has his hands full this season as Killough have introduced teenage brothers Sean Ogand Riain Burnsinto the  to join  year-old Ben McLaughlin, younger brother of winger, Jack.Sean Og has knitted in perfectly at the back alongside Stranney and they will probably be joined by Matthew Burns, Ben McLaughlin or Seamas Tumelty.Goalkeeper Eddie Hinc has already repaid the faith the club has shown in him and he is the perfect replacement for Chris Mallon, who continues to play for the clubrsquos second string.Killough are also spoiled for choice when it comes to their midfield unit.Matt McKiernan will be asked to fill the holding rolehe has recovered from injury, a job he does with consummate easeJust in front of him come the clubrsquos Holy Trinity in skipper Gareth George, Tony McIlhone and Adam George, who is not ing to the USA until the end of the month.Killough play this trio as a central raiding party.They close the opposition down with relish and intensity and force opponents into giving the ball away.However, it will be dficult playing this style on the big pitch at Meadowvale and Killough just might well adopt a new formation.Former Cltonville and Downpatrick FC winger Jack McLaughlin, who missed the semi-final win over Ballynagross due to illness, should start in a wide role leaving Ross Armstrong to play up front on his own.Armstrong is like Stranney, a dedicated, under-rated servant who gives his all and then some more, every time he pulls on a Killough shirtManager John Fitzsimmons, who has never lost a cup final with Killough, feels his side are running into some nice from at the minute and canrsquot wait to get going.ldquoWersquoll let the boys enjoy Christmas day with their families and then get them into the right frame of mind on Boxing Day, he enthused.ldquoWe are going well at the minute and looking forward to the final. The boys are all training hard and we are working on a few dferent permutations for the decider, but it will definitely be horses for courses.ldquoTony McIlhone, Jack McLaughlin and Adam and Gareth George will be key for us in the final. Their experience should stand us in good stead, but I have absolutely no doubt that our young players will rise to the occasion, he added.Fitzsimmons paid tribute to Gerard Kelly, who led the team, to Harry Clarke Cup success last season with Kieran Sharvin and who is still in the management team.ldquoIt is a pleasure and honour to work alongside Gerard, who puts so much effort into keeping the club going. We have been friends for many years and work so well together, he said.ldquoWe have come up with a few ideas on how to get at Ballynahinch Olympic, but we will leave that information to the changing rooms in Meadowvale.Barry McGoran and Marty Sloan have moulded Ballynahinch Olympic Town into a force to be reckoned with, despite the fact that they rarely field with the same  every week due to first team call-ups.As a reserve team, people tend to write them off in the big games, but theyrsquove consistently proved that theyrsquore good enough to compete with anyone.The squad has done exceptionally well to get to another final, but they wont be happy until they get our hands on the cup.McGoran and Sloan like to play the same way as Killough and use the tactic of attack being the best means of defence and Barry feels that Olympic arenrsquot far away from lting the trophy.ldquoWersquore only half way there and need to stay focused. We got a bit carried away last year, but wersquove learnt from that. We need calm heads now, hesaid.ldquoKillough will go into the final as favourites. Theyrsquore a good side with some quality players, especially in midfield and can be lethal going forward, but so can we. We showed that in the semi-final and we have plenty of quality players ourselves.In lsquokeeper John McMenamin Olympic have an experienced custodian, who is a great shot-stopper and as brave as they come.A mixture of Niall McGlew, Mick Rice, Gavin McMullan, Thomas Rodgers Reece McConnell, Darryl Russell and Liam Sloan will make up a formidable defensive barrier with Simon Marmion handed the playmakerrsquos role in the middle of midfield.Shane Rodgers, Simon Marmion, Jack Roddy, Josh Fennell, Gary Wilson, Daniel Rice, Stephen King, Dylan McCartan and Connor Reid will vie for starting places alongside Marmion leaving the twin threat of Darren Lyons and Aaron McCaffrey up front.This pair compliment one and other perfectly.Both are comfortable on the ball and both are workaholics. Defenders canrsquot take an eye off either one as they will destroy you in a flash.McGoran believes his side are ready to cash in on the success of the clubrsquos first team.ldquo The club has come a long way in recent years and when you see the success that our first team is having its incredible, McGoran beamed.ldquoThe professionalism and dedication they show in training has filtered down through the club and it has inspired the younger players to put the work in to try and get to that level mdash and thatrsquos a big part of why our seconds team is doing so well.ldquoLast year ended up being a disappointing Christmas for the club, so itrsquos up to us all to make sure we put things right this time around..prettyPhoto

title: Department ‘has just 8 staff members’ to fix all streets lights in province
story: A LEADING government department has warned that it is not able to operate a full street lighting repair service across the district due to cutbacks.The Department of Infrastructure has revealed that its repair budget has been slashed by two thirds, down from just over poundm to around poundm. In addition, roads officials only have eight electricians to repair faulty street lights across the Province, with just five of these working full-time.The crisis facing street lighting repairs has been highlighted this week by South Down MLA Colin McGrath who has been contacted by many concerned residents across the constituency.He said that the government departmentrsquos failure to sanction work to repair street lights mdash which includes replacing faulty wiring and defective bulbs mdash is a major concern for many, in particular, the vulnerable and elderly.Mr McGrath said that while the issue may appear trivial and mundane to some, to a signicant number of others, itrsquos literally is a matter of personal safety.He said many are fearful of injuring themselves due to faulty street lights which plunge areas around their home into darkness.The MLA declared: ldquoThere is barely a street or road in South Down that does not have street lights which are not working. When there are several defective lights in a row, this creates problems.Mr McGrath said that he and his colleagues have been ldquoinundated with repair requests which are passed on to the departmentrsquos street lighting team.He said that while he is full of admiration for the local team who work tirelessly to resolve faulty streetlights in a professional and courteous way, they can only work with the budget they have been given, one which he said falls well short of what is required.ldquoI have written to the Department for Infrastructure and have found out that the budget for street lighting should be poundm a year. It is currently a mere poundm which is totally inadequate and falls well short of what the public expect, declared Mr McGrath.ldquoApparently, there are only eight full time staff managing the work of replacing and fixing street lights across the whole of North and this is wholly unacceptable. Eight staff from Derry toNewry, and Enniskillen to Ballycastle is not enough and represents a situation that demands action.The MLA confirmed that he has also raised his concerns with the permanent secretary at the helm of the government department asking that in the depths of winter and reduced daylight hours, additional funding will be made to address the issue.Mr McGrath added: ldquoWe are literally in the dark over what will happen next and need to see some solution to this problem.A spokeswoman for the Department for Infrastructure has confirmed that officials have discussed the street lighting situation with Mr McGrath.ldquoWhilst we appreciate his concerns, we have explained that in common with many other parts of the public service, the Department continues to face budget challenges and resources are not available to provide for a full street lighting repair service, she continued.ldquoThe Departmentrsquos current budget for street lighting repairs is approximately poundm, which is much lower than the pound.m that would be required to provide a full street lighting repair service.The spokeswoman explained that repairs are now generally limited to those that can be carried out by the departmentrsquos internal street lighting workforce, which consists of five full time and three part time electricians.She added: ldquoDue to the restricted service, outages may take much longer than usual to be repaired, with priority being given to hazardous electrical defects and group outages..prettyPhoto

title: Devaney elected as new chairman of Down GAA
story: DOWN GAA elected a new chairman at the annual convention in Newry last Wednesday evening. Bredaghrsquos John Devaney becomes the st holder of the countyrsquos main position, having been selected unopposed to succeed Mayobridge man Sean Rooney.In his first address to delegates, Mr Devaney outlined a strategic vision for the association in the county and a number of areas of focus for his term of office.The key priorities will be the proposed Centre of Excellence, the development of a new coaching plan, recruitment of referees, and a programme to encourage and nurture new and young administrators.Following his election, Devaney said: ldquoThe Ballykinlar Centre of Excellence is clearly the single biggest project that we will have undertaken, and will take time and resource to bring to fruition. ldquoWe have set out our intention and we are determined that it will happen, because it is a fantastic opportunity for the county. But it is only the only project.ldquoThere is quite a lot we can achieve in other areas, on and off the fields of play. Coaching, refereeing, administration, club development and fundraising will also require our attention, he added.ldquoAnd we also want to have the ambition for our teams to reach their potential and challenge for honours. So, the future has real potential for us, but it will require a lot of support, goodwill and a unity of purpose across the county. A native of Killoe in Co Longford, Devaney has been an officer with Down GAA since . He is a former chairman of the Queenrsquos University GAA club and the Higher Education GAA Council, and has served on Ulster Council Management Committee and Central Council.Further details on the proposed new Centre of Excellence at Ballykinlar were outlined at Wednesdayrsquos meeting.Planning permission for the development was submitted earlier last week and the early concept designs of the complex were presented to club delegates. The site at the Ministry of Defence base will encompass four pitches, a MUGA and an administration and exhibition museum centre. Down GAA will now plan to appoint a Project Board in the New Year.Maureen OrsquoHigginswas elected as the new vice-chairperson of the board, on an evening when a number of officerships changed hands.Outgoing chairman Sean Rooney was selected to represent the county on the Ulster Council alongside Sean McCashin. Donal McNallywill assume the position of Irish and Cultural Officer, while Drumgathrsquos Michael McArdle is the new delegate to Central Council.As a result of disciplined financial management in recent years, the presentation of the financial report by treasurer Diarmuid Cahill showed a strong position for the county moving forward.Fourteen motions on the convention agenda were all approved, including ten proposals to go forward to the GAA Congress in Dublin at the end of February. These include: points deduction as a penalty option for a breach of the rule on lsquomisconduct considered to have discredited the association removing the rule which allows a newly-transferred player to finish playing in a competition he had started with his former club a  month hiatus on a further transfer for a player after his transfer has been granted adult inter-club championship games to be extended to  minutes per half.Convention also approved a proposal for the GAA to engage with RTEacute on extending their TV competition provisions to allow entry from viewers in Northern Ireland.Officers elected at the  annual convention: chairman, John Devaneyvice-chairperson, Maureen OrsquoHigginssecretary: Seaacuten Oacuteg McAteer treasurer, Diarmuid Cahillassistant secretary, Michael OrsquoRourkeassistant treasurer, Brendan FitzpatrickPRO, Fiona MurphyDevelopment Officer, Willie GribbenIrish and Culture Officer, Donal McNallyCentral Council delegate, Michael McArdleUlster Council delegates, Sean Rooneyand Sean McCashin ..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick couple enjoy 65 years of marital bliss
story: A DOWNPATRICK couple whose introduction was gently engineered by the husband-to-bersquos mother will celebrate  years of marriage on Saturday.Muriel and Alan Major will be surrounded by family and friends when they mark their blue sapphire anniversary.Muriel and Alan, who are both  and from Saul Road, admit they found a ldquogem in each other.They credit their long and happy marriage to a shared love of musicand the arts and never allowing a disagreement to remain too long without making up.The couple say that they have been blessed with three sons, Glenn, Richard and Ian, two grandchildren, Hannah and Thomas, and two great-children, Louis and Lila.They were married at the age of  in Ballyphilip Parish Church, Portaferry, by the Rev Lindsay on December ,. Like many other couples of that era, the wedding was a small affair and they spent a welcome few days honeymooning in Dublin.Alan worked as a writer in the Supply and Secretariat branch of the Royal Navy and soon needed to leave his new bride at home toto his posting. Muriel worked in the office of the now defunct Ulster Transport company.They met on a bus from Belfast to Portaferry and the rest, as they say, is history.ldquoI think we were both on the bus from Belfast and my mother, who knew Muriel, sat beside her and they began to talk and then we were introduced, said Alan. ldquoI was sitting behind and my mother then invited her down for supper the next night.Muriel interjected jokingly: ldquoI was supposed to be going to a shorthand class, which would have made my dear father much happier, but I mitched off and went to the Ritz pictures instead.ldquoHis mother had already spotted me and approved me as a likely candidate for her son as she believed that I knew how to keep house since I was doing it at home as my mother died when I was very young.Alan said that his motherrsquos approval of Muriel very much matched his own.ldquoI had clapped eyes on her before and I thought she will do very nicely for me. It was a private thought, but my mother must have picked up on it and had some insight, he added.Muriel did come for supper the next night and an invitation to a dance was given by Alan. They courted for over a year and more whenever he was home on leave.Alanrsquos parents, Rachel and Ian, were in the next room when Alan later asked Muriel to marry him and they celebrated with tea and supper again.ldquoI was completely flabbergasted but I would say that it was a romantic proposal, recalled Muriel. ldquoAlanrsquos father was great at tending to an open fire in the sitting room and his mother was a great hostess in making scones and cake for supper, so I think just after his father tended the fire, Alan turned tome and asked me to marry me. I think I said yes with a laugh as it was so unexpected.The couple spent the early years of their marriage in Malta where Alan was stationed and where the eldest two sons where born.While the family spent a short time living in Bangor, they have spent the last  years living Downpatrick where Alan went on to work for Radio Rentals in the town, and later in the British Red Cross Society in Belfast, while Muriel worked for the Saul playgroup and later in Downpatrick Library.The couplersquos love of music and going to the theatre, both in Belfast, and at the former Theatre Upstairs, in Irish Street, Downpatrick, was a shared passion over the years.Even today, they both love to watch or listen to concerts on the radio or TV, with performances perking up them up from a trying day or calling on their Alexa to play some Glen Miller music.Muriel said: ldquoWe both love the theatre and we both absolutely love music of all sorts. If therersquos anything that doesnrsquot suit us, we have a wee word with Alexa and say itrsquos your turn to chose.Alan added: ldquoIrsquove often said isnrsquot it wonderful that we have the same tastes in common and thatrsquos a great start to a marriage as well as a good sense of humour and a short memory.Muriel said: ldquoI think it did help that we did like the same things but I would say donrsquot leave it too long before you say sorry for whatever may have happened or been said between you. Itrsquos best done before the night is out.ldquoAlso, I say that having a bit of good manners helps, to say thank you and to appreciate what we do for each other..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick man in roll of honour
story: FORMER Downpatrick and Ireland cricket captain Alfie Linehan was included in a prestigious roll of honour of international sports personalities who died during .He was among  from around the world listed as lsquospecial peoplersquo in BBC Televisionrsquos Sports Personality of the Year programme broadcast at the weekend.They included England goalkeeper Gordon Banks and racing driver Niki Lauda as well as another cricketer mdash one of Englandrsquos greatest fast bowlers, Bob Willis.Alfie died in June after suffering dementia and contracting cancer. He was .He helped take Downpatrick to five senior league and three cup titles and, as a free scoring batsman, captained Ireland in the s. He was also a leading administrator at local and national level.ldquoIt was a lovely surprise for Alfie to be honoured in this way, said his widow, Mary, at her home at Ardmeen outside Downpatrick.ldquoI was on the phone when the item came on and thought I caught Alfiersquos picture. When I wound it back, indeed it was Alfie. I was so surprised, but really pleased.Cricket was to the forefront throughout the programme. England all rounder Ben Stokes won the top inidual award and World Cup winners England took the international team award, collected by Dublin-born captain Eoin Morgan..prettyPhoto

title: Dundrum senior citizens get into festive spirit at Christmas dinner
story: SENIOR citizens in Dundrum enjoyed their annual Christmas dinner on Saturday.Staff and helpers at the Dundrum Inn treated over  pensioners to a sumptuous dinner with all the trimmings and also ensured their glasses were filled to the brim.Local man Wilfie Swain extended his gratitude to everyone who helped make the occasion possible.He paid particular thanks to the Dundrum Development Association who sponsored the event, Paddy Cunningham of Dundrum Flowers, who supplied Santa gts, and Francie Cunningham who kept the party swinging with his excellent music and vocals.Thanks were also extended to the Dundrum Inn, the kitchen staff and waiters for their hard work and keeping everything running smoothly.He added: ldquoThanks also to Santa, who, although is very busy this time of year, made a surprise visit to the event with a gt in hand for everyone..prettyPhoto

title: Exasperation over £46m Newry investment ‘with none for Downpatrick’
story: A POLITICIAN has accused council officials and some councillors of favouring Newry over Downpatrick when it comes to public investment.Cllr Cadogan Enright claims there is a ldquomassive investment imbalance between both towns, suggesting that poundm is earmarked for Newry town centre and nothing for the heart of Downpatrick.The claim mdash which has been rejected by Newry, Mourne and Down Council mdash came after Cllr Enright attended a recent meeting organised by the local authority.He claims he discovered during the meeting at the Down Arts Centre that the town centrersquos masterplan had been ldquohugely downscaled with no one-way traffic system and no public money to develop the former police station site and adjacent empty buildings.Cllr Enright said it was his understanding that the redevelopment of this huge site, which stretches back as far as St Patrickrsquos Avenue and is adjacent to the Irish Street car park, will be dependent on a private developer coming forward to revitalise the near four acre town centre location.He said that during another meeting in Newry, plans were published for public expenditure in the city centre with the major investment initiative funded by the local authority , City Dealand private investment . Cllr Enrightrsquos assertion has been rejected by council officials.ldquoThe long-standing plans to publicly finance the redevelopment of public lands in Downpatrick town centre have been abandoned, he claimed.Cllr Enright said business representatives who attended the meeting in Downpatrick were not informed that a proposed road linking Irish Street with St Patrickrsquos Avenue as part of a new one-way system was not proceeding.He said such a scheme mdash which roads officials have said is not viable given the cost and the small impact that it would have on congestion mdash would have eliminated the need for traffic lights on all the main junctions and ldquomassively reduced congestion around the centre of town.Cllr Enright claimed that when he queried the decision, he was informed that the councilrsquos priorities are the Ballynahinch bypass and Newryrsquos southern relief road.He added: ldquoAll this comes hot on the heels of the scandalous proposed closure of Downpatrickrsquos visitor information centre in favour of Newry, progressing greenways around Newry but not Downpatrick and the abandonment of the promised Edward Street one-way system, which was supposed to have been delivered on a short-term basis in  until the new council revisited the roads priority list.A Newry, Mourne and Down Council spokeswoman said the local authority has allocated poundm to the Newry City Centre regenerationproject, with poundm secured from the Belfast Regional City Deal, not the poundm quoted by Cllr Enright.She continued: ldquoIt has been proposed that the development of Downpatrick town centre and the old PSNI station should be done collaboratively between local and central government with intervention from other public sector bodies.ldquoThis remains the case. However, the one-way system for Downpatrick town centre was considered by Transport NI who have advised that this is not viable.The spokeswoman also confirmed that a report was tabled to the local authorityrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourismlast month which considered the future opportunities for visitor information centres within the district.She added: ldquo This report was held lsquoin committeersquo and no decisions have been made by Newry, Mourne and Down Council with regards to the closures of existing visitor information centres. The future provision of visitor information services will be tabled at the ERT Committee in due course..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C December 18%2C 1979
story: DOWNPATRICK mdash The opening date for Downpatrickrsquos new swimming pool still remains unknown, but it now seems unlikely that it will be ready for public use before next summer.At the moment that shock prediction suits local councillors who are not yet prepared for an early finish to the work. If the pool is completed soon it would probably lie idle because pool staff have not yet been appointed.The situation has left councillors with red faces for the second time in several months. They have been pushing relentlessly for early completion, but have made no preparations to coincide with a possible quick finish.Last month they demanded a showdown with the poolrsquos architects and had even threatened to invoke penalty clauses on the contractthe pool was not finished soon. They were due to meet the architects this week, but instead were sent a written report on the progress being made.The council clerk, Mr Seamus Byrne, read the report at a council meeting on Monday and said he expected a completion date early in the new year. In the report the architects catalogued a series of setbacks over the past two years and blamed most of the delay on strikes and shortages of materials.Downpatrick councillor, Mr Sean Quinn, launched into a scathing attack on the architects, who, he said, had failed to serve the council as they as they should.Mr Quinn said he found it disturbing that the architects must have known of the troubles on the site, yet had still made ldquowild predictions about the proposed opening date.Mr Quinn also condemned the mounting costs of work on the scheme and then drew attention to the pool itself, saying he felt the interior design was lacking in imagination.Mr Cecil Maxwell reminded councillors that they had approved the pool design and he did not think the architects were at fault for the slow progress.DROMARA mdash ADromara schoolgirl flies out to London tomorrow to represent Northern Ireland in a major essay competition. Sixteen year-old Christine Moore, a pupil at St Colmanrsquos High School in Ballynahinch, is one of  finalists from across the UK in the Sundayessay competition.She has already impressed the judges with her entry on the theme of energy conservation, its economic importance and effect upon western Europe during the next decade.Christine, a sixth form student, could find herself among a shortlist of six finalists after interviews with the City Editor of the Sundayand the senior vice-president of the First National Bank of Chicago.The finalists will be entertained to lunch at the Inn on the Park Hotel, London. The Energy Minister, Mr David Howell, will present a pound cheque to the winner.Christine is the daughter of Mr and Mrs W Moore,  Artana Road, Dromara. She is at present studying for two A Levels in Economics and Accounts.NEWCASTLE mdash Plans to turn Newcastlersquos Percy French Festival into a fully fledged festival of international standing were revealed this week mdash and the Northern Ireland Tourist Board has promised to throw its weight behind it.Already an annual Percy French festival week is held in the town, but now the Tourist Board has come up with an offer of substantial grant aid over the next three years to make it even bigger and better.Plans for the festival were outlined at a meeting of the Heart of Down Accommodation Association in Newcastle with tourist officials and Down District Council. A special festival steering committee has been formed, including representatives of the three bodies.A spokesman for the Tourist Board said: ldquoThe poems, paintings, anecdotes and songs of Percy French, topped, of course, by The Mountains of Mourne, form a magnicent treasure house of tourist material.ldquoWe have no doubt thatthis product is carefully packaged and projected to the world at large, Newcastle in the years to come could have a wonderfully successful festival.ldquoNot only would members of the public enjoy the entertainment, but we believe that many international stars of present day music hall and cabaret would wish to join in celebrating the memory of this talented troubadour.SAINTFIELD mdash The headmaster of Saintfield High School, Mr Ronnie MacPherson, has urged education chiefs to give financial incentives to school teachers.Mr MacPherson was speaking at his schoolrsquos annual prize distribution on Monday night and he also called on teachersrsquo unions to play a more positive role in education.In a hard-hitting speech he told his audience that the morale of the teaching profession was as low as it has probably ever been.ldquoThe public at large have no idea of how serious the situation is in educational institutions and no lessons seem to have been learned by the open signs of unrest seen this year, he said.Mr MacPherson stressed that the importance of schools could not be underestimated. ldquoNext to home the school is the most crucial place for the moral, mental and physical development of citizens. A solution must be found to raise the morale of teachers, he remarked.ldquoWhy is it that teachers today are changing their chosen profession, or taking a second job to supplement their incomes. Teachersrsquo unions will fail the professionthey continue trying to score points off each other and do not unite in seeking wise solutions to the present problems.KILLYLEAGH mdash Killyleagh Parish Scouts won the district challenge shield held in the townrsquos high school on Friday night.They had to beat off a strong challenge from the st Downpatrick troop and the outcome of the competition was not decided until the last game, with more than  boys taking part.The district commissioner, Mr Harry Galbraith, handed over to the shield to Stephen Patterson on behalf of the winning troop.The evening was organised by Robert Sharpe, assistant scout leader with Downpatrick, assisted by Glenn Houston, assistant scout leader at Killyleagh.It was a double night of celebration for the Killyleagh troop because they were also awarded the coveted Scout achievement award.BALLYNAHINCH mdash A pound, cheque, the proceeds of a mammoth bring and buy sale in Ballynahinch, was handed over to Oxfam this week and will be used to buy medical supplies and foodstuffs for the Kampuchean refugees.The cheque was handed over by the Rev James Lamont to Annie Hamilton, assistant regional secretary of Oxfam, on behalf of the organisers of the sale which was held in Magheradroll Parish Church Hall last month.This was a tremendous effort in such a short time by the organising committee and townspeople, and thanks must go to Mrs Olive Mateer, committed chairman, Mrs Malachy McCauley and Miss Colette Bonner, secretary, the committee members, the public who helped support the venture, the Rev C W M Cooper and select vestry of Magheradroll Parish Church and the Rev Lamont and members of st Ballynahinch Presbyterian Church for their help.ARDGLASS mdash Councillor Dermot Curran has won the fight to get priority for the development of playing fields in Ardglass. This week Down councillors agreed to move Ardglass to the top of a list of work to be supplied to Enterprise Ulster.Last month the councilrsquos recreation committee had drawn up a priority list with the Ardglass scheme lying second to work on the Plank Drain in Downpatrick. Mr Curran reminded councillors that the Ardglass scheme had been shelved for far too long and he asked for the list to be revised.CASTLEWELLAN mdash Police in Castlewellan have received a number of complaints about dogs roaming in the Bunkers Hill and St Malachyrsquos area of the town. The complaints have been coming from local residents, particularly older people, and police are appealing to dog owners to keep their animals under control..prettyPhoto

title: Hazzard retains top spot in South Down
story: SINN Feinrsquos Chris Hazzard has retained his South Down Westminster seat. He topped the poll at last weekrsquos parliamentary election with , votes to hold on to the seat he won from the SDLP in , holding off the challenge from the nationalist partyrsquos Michael Savage in his first Westminster contest.Mr Hazzard mdash who ended three decades of SDLP domination in  when he defeated Margaret Ritchie mdash saw his vote decline by almost ,, a decrease of . per cent in a pro-remain constituency.The Sinn Fein manrsquos majority ped from , in  to ,, but he still had enough in the tank to retain his seat.Interestingly, the number of people who voted in South Down last Thursday decreased by almost . per cent mdash down from , in  to ,. And while almost , people cast their vote, just over , eligible voters across the constituency chose not to go the polls.While Mr Hazzard was viewed by many as the runaway favourite, he admitted that he took nothing for granted and worked hard to ensure that republicans retained their grip on the Westminster seat for another term.Mr Hazzard said Sinn Feinrsquos commitment to stand up for people when it came to Brexit and give them a voice was a message that resonated with the South Down electorate. He said that in the light of the ldquoBrexit catastrophe, people stood up and put the interests of people in the constituency to the fore.Conceding that he expected his vote to decease, the ing MP said that he was delighted to top the poll, highlighting the need to get Stormont up and running again.ldquoIt is important that we have locally devolved institutions. There was a deal on the table last year which I thought was a good compromise. No deal is going to be perfect and all parties need to realise that we are going to have to give a wee bit to get back in, he said. ldquoWe want locally elected ministers involved in decision making.ldquoWe want to restore Stormont and are very keen to get a deal to move forward to restore the institutions to tackle the issues around health, education and infrastructure.The SDLPrsquos Michael Savage said the gap between nationalists and republicans across the constituency was ldquonarrowing and believed his party had a solid  on which to plan for future electoral success.ldquoI will sit down with the team to assess how the election went, looking at the missed opportunities and the things we did well and build on those, he said.ldquoThere was an opportunity tonight in South Down and some voters may reflect on that and sayonly we had done this or that. In the end, it just wasnrsquot to be. I have been around a long time and just have to accept that that is democracy and politics can be cruel at times, but I enjoyed every minute of it.Mr Savage added: ldquoA lot of people wrote us off in  and said the SDLP was finished. We have a lot of very good, talented young people coming through and, as far as I am concerned, we have a bright future ahead of us. I think what our results have shown tonight is that people have realised that stalemate politics and power splitting, rather than power-sharing, is not working for the people of Northern Ireland.The DUPrsquos Glyn Hanna, who saw his party vote decrease by just over two per cent mdash down from , in  to , mdash said he was pleased the DUP remained ldquothe voice of unionism in South Down on what had been a disappointing night for his party where, particularly in North and South Belfast.He said that the election count had been a ldquotough night for unionism explaining that he was not disappointed with his own performance in an ldquounforeseen election.Mr Hanna added: ldquoIt is important that the DUP remains the voice of unionism in South Down and it is going to stay that way as we have a solid voice and a firm Assembly seat. On the doorstep, people said they wanted the Assembly up and running and I think that that is going to happen.Alliancersquos Patrick Brown was delighted to increase the partyrsquos vote by over  per cent.In  the party polled , votes which Brown increase to , votes last week, placing Alliance fourth in the South Down pecking order, just  votes behind the DUP.The Alliance man believes that the only way to unite people in South Down is toa cross-community candidate to Westminster, suggesting that the surge in support for his party was because people are ldquofed up with the current situation at Stormont.Brown also believes that Alliance is potentially edging towards a South Down Assembly seat given the strong constituency base that it now has and that he would be up for contesting any future election.Ulster Unionist Jill Macauley mdash who was delighted to increase the party vote by just over three percent mdash rising from , votes two years ago to , this time out, was one of bright lights of her partyrsquos Westminster campaign.She was delighted to increase the vote at what she described as ldquoturbulent political times and said it was clear on the doorstep that voters are angry with the conduct of the DUP and Sinn Fein and their lack of delivery.ldquoThe clear message from the electorate was that they want local politicians to get back to work and restore the Assembly and the Executive. The current health crisis was also a major concern and the impending emergency that faces our strangled education system, she said.ldquoWith the UUP share of the vote increasing in such a toxic environment, it encourages me that we must be doing something right. I hope voters will continue to put their faith in the Ulster Unionist Party as a vehicle in which unionism can move forward as an inclusive and modern movement, instead of the politics of fear we have all come to know.Aontuacute, which was contesting its first Westminster election, polled , votes,  less than the collective performance of its three candidates at the recent Newry, Mourne and Down Council election..prettyPhoto

title: I’m here to serve you%2C says Shannon
story: STRANGFORD MP Jim Shannon secured another convincing victory mdash albeit with a reduced vote mdash for the third time in last weekrsquos general election.The overall Strangford turnout vote was also down, just .% of the eligible electorate compared to .% turnout in .While Mr Shannon topped the poll with , votes out of , valid votes, it was a %on his last thumping win when he was the DUP MP with the biggest majority.This year that honour went to Ian Paisley in North Antrim, who was nearly , votes clear of his nearest rival.A committed Christian and a pro-le advocate, Mr Shannon appealed to nearly half of the Strangford voters, earning a . % share of the vote in what was always a one-horse race.However, as he and his election team stood while Stephen Farryrsquos North Down win for Alliance was announced at Bangorrsquos Aurora Centre around am on Friday morning, there was an air of sombreness and distinct lack of celebration mdash perhaps due to news which had filtered through that party colleagues Nigel Dodds and Emma Little-Pengelly were in danger of losing their seats.The ing officer seemed to be in a rush to make the Strangford announcement as Dr Farry was unable to make his acceptance speech until after Mr Shannonrsquos victory was announced.Mr Shannonrsquos  year-old mother, Mona, who lives near Kircubbin, was there to support him, as was his we, Sandra. Along with Rowallane councillor Billy Walker, they waited respectfully to let Dr Farry have his moment ahead of the Strangford vote confirmation.In his acceptance speech, Mr Shannon firstly thanked God for this victory, then his family, election agent Michelle McIlveen and his canvassing team, and all of those who ldquokept him in their prayers during the campaign.He added: ldquoI want to thank the people of Strangford for their endorsement for the overwhelming vote for myself and the Democratic Unionist Party. I want to assure everyone in Strangford, whether you voted for me or not, Irsquom your MP and Irsquom here to serve you the same as everyone .Mr Shannon said he believed the election was about two things mdash the non-ing Northern Ireland Assembly and the Union. He said he listened on the doorsteps about the importance of preserving the Union which had been ldquodegraded and downgraded by Boris Johnston.He then said what he thought of the prime minister. ldquoHersquos the sort of man who would take your Alsatian dog for a walk and hersquod come back an hour later and give you a Chihuahua and say it was alright.ldquoSo we need to convince Boris Johnston of the importance of the union, and that we the DUP, even though our numbers are lower, that its very important that we work to the union for those who live in Leicester, London, Manchester or wherever  in the United Kingdom, is the same for the people of Strangford.Later, he admitted he had estimated that his vote would have been lower.He said: ldquoI had already made my prediction [before the nightrsquos result] and it was slightly below what I got, but I knew there would be a big dference as the vote was exceptional the last time and something I never expected.Once again Mr Shannonrsquos nearest rival was Alliance candidate Kellie Armstrong. She acknowledged Mr Shannonrsquos ldquofair fight in her speech.Riding the crest of the Alliance wave evidenced throughout the province, she nearly doubled her vote, gaining , votescompared to her  outing where she secured , votes.Comber councillor Philip Smith maintained the third place gained by former party leader Mike Nesbitt in . However, it was with a reduced vote. He polled , votes, .% of the total vote, but it was down .% in vote share.SDLP candidate, Portaferry councillor Joe Boyle, came in fourth once more with , votes,  down from .One of the minor surprises of the Strangford was how the Conservative candidate, Grant Abraham, supplanted Sinn Fein to come in fth place.Mr Abraham, an international commercial lawyer and farmer from the Saintfield area, gained a creditable , votes on his first outing compared to the  party colleague Claire Hiscott polled in the  election.The Green Partyrsquos Maurice Macartney managed to increase the partyrsquos vote by nearly a third on , by polling  votes to come in sixth place, compared to Ricky Bamfordrsquos  votes.Mr Macartney succeeded in pushing Sinn Feinrsquos Ryan Carlin into seventh place. Mr Carlin received  votes, votes ahead of the UKIP candidate, Robert Stephenson, who came in last place..prettyPhoto

title: Kind Rory’s  Christmas collection
story: A KIND-HEARTED Kilclief boy has been responding to a local radio stationrsquos Christmas appeal in a big way.Eight year-old Rory Lenaghan has collected over  gts for babies and teenagers across Northern Ireland who would have very little gts to unwrap this Christmasit was not for him and the generosity of the local people.This is the fth year the P pupil, who attends St Malachyrsquos Primary School in Kilclief, has called on local people to donate toward Mission Christmas Appeal on Cool FM.His mother, Oonagh, says Rory has a huge heart for someone so small and gets very happy when he sees all the gts arrive for the children.She said: ldquoDocrsquos Fish and Chips in Downpatrick, Ardglass and Newcastle offered to be collection points for Roryrsquos appeal. They set up boxes for people to place their gts which has made it very accessible indeed.ldquoIrsquom always amazed at the generosity of the Co Down people. The big demand recently is for babies and teenagers and people donate new gts of make-up sets, hat and glove sets and toddlerrsquos toys, which we gratefully appreciate.ldquoEvery year we see people who are on benefits and donrsquot have much themselves donate the biggest bags. We are always very humbled by it.Rory, who has donated over  gts since he began collecting almost five years ago, is helped by his little two year-old sister, Fianna, and his cousins.Oonagh says sometimes people deliver presents for the appeal to their front door and Fianna begins to jump up and down with excitement, because she thinks they might be for her.ldquoRory, however takes great delight in being able to help other children who are less fortunate than himself. He tells me all the time thateveryone did a collection like this poverty would not exist and people would have enough.ldquoWe donrsquot know peoplersquos financial situation. I tell my children that Santa has to be paid for all the gts he delivers on Christmas Eve. I think itrsquos important children learn that money doesnrsquot grow on trees and that way they learn the value of it.ldquoWhen Rory celebrated his third birthday we had a party for him at the Ballymote Centre. Instead of presents, Rory wanted people to donate toward the childrenrsquos charity NSPCC.ldquoHe raised almost pound and the delight he took in knowing children just like him would feel happier as a result of this, was something .Oonagh says she is always amazed when she meets people who tell her they donrsquot trust charities.She said: ldquoMy response to them is always the same. We canrsquot adopt that attitude because together we can do an awful lot. When I was growing up I watched my own mother and father be very charitable to local causes and I think it has rubbed off on all of us.ldquoSometimes we watch as little Rory would give you the the shirt of his backhe thought you might need it and we think he is an example to all of us.Oonagh wishes to thank everyone who has donated gts to this yearrsquos appeal, as well as Caroline and Morgan Morrisson from Docrsquos Fish and Chips and Ardglass GAC for kindly helping to promote Roryrsquos appeal..prettyPhoto

title: Nurses and health workers on strike seeking pay parity
story: HUNDREDS of local nurses and health workers are striking today to demand pay parity with counterparts in the rest of the UK.Members of the Royal College of Nursing will be joining members from Unison, Unite and NIPSA in the strike action from am to pm.The workers are also calling for nursing numbers to be increased as they claim that the health service is close to breaking point.The strike will impact on hospital and community services, but unions confirmed thatsufficient nurses will remain working at the Downe and Downshire Hospitals to ensure patient safety.Doctors will not be taking part in the strike action but the majority of other healthcare staff will be participting, including paramedics.The South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust last night warned the public to ldquoexpect widespread cancellations and disruption to services.Last night Unisonrsquos Down branch secretary, Marian Ritchie, said that she doubted any th hour pay offer would be made.She added: ldquoThe Secretary of State has been called back to Parliament so it leaves only the Permanent Secretary, Richard Pengelly, here to make any offer. He has said before that he doesnrsquot have the authority, yet he made the last offer.She stressed that none of the union members wanted to take strike action but felt compelled to do so as a last resort.Speaking as her union entered the fourth week of industrial action, she said: ldquoThe fact that Unison, RCN, Unite and NIPSA are all taking strike action today reinforces the fact that health care staff feel passionately about the preservation of the NHS and want to restore it to a service that they can be proud of again and will last for generations to come.ldquoAgain we ask the public to support us as they have previously and join us in the fight to restore our health service to a high standard.She called on recently elected MPs to fulfil their promises of support at last weekrsquos strike and added: ldquoWe look to our local MLAs, Department of Health officials and the Secretary of State to address these issues now.She said that Unison would like to thank local businesses which provided the striking staff with food and refreshments during this time, in particular Molloyrsquos in Downpatrick  A in Crossgar, and Down Community Health Committee members for their support..prettyPhoto

title: Sinn Fein's candidate sails home on night of drama at Titanic Centre
story: THE re-election of Chris Hazzard largely went under the radar at last weekrsquos election count in Belfast.Originally due to take place in Magherafelt, the South Down count was switched to the Titanic Exhibition Centre in Belfast in the shadow of the iconic Harland and Wolff shipyard and its imposing Sampson and Goliath cranes which dominate the city skyline.The mainstream media effectively ignored the South Down contest in the run-up to last weekrsquos election and, during the counting of votes across six constituencies in the huge Titanic centre, it was more of the same.Predictably, the media focus was on the North and South Belfast seats where DUP heavyweights Nigel Dodds and Emma Little-Pengelly lost out to Sinn Feinrsquos John Finucane and the SDLPrsquos Claire Hanna respectively.Television cameras were focused on the reaction of the winners and losers in the Belfast constituencies and the arrival of DUP leader Arlene Foster mdash on what was a particularly dficult night for her party mdash and Sinn Fein president Mary Lou McDonald and the republican partyrsquos northern leader Michelle OrsquoNeill.Mr Hazzard, who made history two years ago when he broke the SDLPrsquos -year stranglehold on the South Down seat, was officially declared the winner shortly before .am, but his acceptance speech was brief. As was that of SDLP runner-up Michael Savage.They were the only two South Down candidates who made their way to the podium to thank those who voted for them on a night when Northern Irelandrsquos political environment changed signicantly.With voters across the province electing a majority of nationalist MPs for the first time, it truly was a night of edge-of-the-seat political drama. Itrsquos often said that first itrsquos news then its history, but at the Belfast county centre news and history were inextricably intertwined.Minutes after the South Down result had been declared, the glare of the media spotlight was on official confirmation that the DUP had lost South Belfast.As SDLP supporters and the party faithful cheered loudly for Claire Hanna, the Sinn Fein contingent took a moment out of celebrating Mr Hazzardrsquos victory to watch proceedings.Hazzard was always the favourite for the South Down seat and used a sporting analogy to explain how he felt about the contest. He said favourites donrsquot always win, pointing out how hard he worked on the ground, emphasising that the was never complacent about the challenge he faced from the SDLP.From early in the count, SDLP members said that it looked as though their man was in with a real fighting chance and from the boxes which had been opened, the duo were neck and neck.While some of the Sinn Fein contingent appeared to be sporting furrowed brows early into the counting process, they were always confident that their man would emerge victorious and that he did, albeit with a reduced majority.There were suggestions that unionist voters in the Crossgar area had backed Mr Savage, who was clear throughout his campaign that he would not only be an MP for all, but one who would take his seat in the House of Commons.And while it was reported close between him and Mr Hazzard at one stage, the Sinn Fein man eased ahead in the race to cross the winning line, with the SDLP man left wondering what might have been.He had been given a relatively short lead-in time to last weekrsquos parliamentary pole and while pleased with his performance, he clearly felt he could have done even better and pushed the Sinn Fein man all the way to the line.Elsewhere, Alliancersquos Patrick Brown was one of a number of his partyrsquos candidates who built on their recent success at the EU and local council elections.The Westminster poll was viewed as a key litmus test that would rigorously challenge Alliancersquos recent election surge in a first past the post electoral system which did not rely on the votes of other parties.Mr Brown, who in May trebled his Newry, Mourne and Down Council vote in Rowallane, was at it again. His election agent and fellow councillor, Andrew McMurray, stood for Alliance in  and polled , votes, but Brown more than trebled the Alliance vote, a performance which helped his party leapfrog the Ulster Unionists to become the third largest in the province. Overall, Alliancersquos vote in South Down increased by an impressive . per cent, marking a remarkable performance by Brown.Most signicantly, Alliance now has its eyes focused firmly on securing an Assembly seat and while Mr Brown refused to be drawn on whether he would like his name to go forward should such a contest arise, there is no doubt that he will be the partyrsquos preferred candidate. He left the count centre a happy man his stock within his party continues to rise.Elsewhere, the DUPrsquos Glyn Hanna was pleased with his performance, despite his vote decreasing, and he didnrsquot rule out being the partyrsquos flag bearer in a future Assembly electionthis weekrsquos talks at Stormont fail to restore the power-sharing executive.Ulster Unionist, Jill Macauley, defied pundits suggestions that her party would not do well in South Down, by increasing the UUP vote by almost three per cent.Province-wide, the UUP polled , votes but with a new leader in charge the party did not produce the performance it had been hoping for. However, Mrs Macauley provided it with a glimmer of hope with her performanceAontuacute mdash which was contesting its first election mdash polled , votes but party candidate, Paul Brady, wasnrsquot at the count centre in Belfast where party leader Peader Tobin did call late on Thursday evening.As the last of the media interviews were conducted, television and radio sound engineers were doing their best to drown out the clatter of chairs being piled on top of one another and folding tables used by counting staff collapsed to be packed away.The last of the candidates, party supporters, election staff and the media started to drt away from the Titanic Exhibition Centre around .am, following another night of high drama which signicantly reshaped the provincersquos political landscape..prettyPhoto

title: Special gift for Lorcán
story: CHRISTMAS came early for Downpatrick toddler Lorcaacuten Maguire who received his first dose of le-extending medication yesterday.His parents have been campaigning to get the expensive drug Orkambi free on the NHS since Lorcaacuten, who has Cystic Fibrosis , was just a few months old.Brave Lorcaacuten, who turns three next month, took his drug at the Royal Belfast Hospital for Sick Children with the help of some strawberry-flavoured milk.However, it was a bittersweet moment for his mother, Jen Banks, as she knows that other parents of children are still patiently waiting for the drug to became available.She said: ldquoLast Christmas I was dreaming about getting Orkambi but it was a dream that would have meant leaving my home, family, and our amazing NHS to move to the south.ldquoThis year on Christmas morning Lorcaacuten will open his stocking and before he opens the rest of his presents, he will have his morning dose of Orkambi with a few segments of chocolate orange. I am so joyful and thankful as is my husband Dermot and our families.Orkambi was made available freely available following a surprise move by Department of Health Permanent Secretary Richard Pengelly at the end of October.Scotland and the Republic of Ireland made the drug free available to CF sufferers earlier but NHS England wrangled with the drug company over price.Once a deal was agreed in England, it paved the pay for Northern Ireland to introduce Orkambi for patients as young as Lorcaacuten, along with Symkevi, which can be given to children aged  and over.Jen was only informed on Monday that the drug was available for Lorcaacuten following a phone call from his treatment nurse.She said: ldquoI was absolutely shaking holding the phone when they told me that Lorcaacuten could get his medication as he has been fighting off the pseudomonas infection since last November.ldquoOrkambi was being given to those children with the higher clinical need and Lorcaacuten got it because of his infection, but I know of so many other families who have campaigned long and hard as we have.ldquoItrsquos just a matter of sufficient quantities of the drug becoming available as I know that the medical teams are working around the clock to distribute to as many patients as they can.Lorcaacuten was observed for five hours in hospital before he was allowed to go home with what his mother calls his ldquomagic medicine. He will need to take it twice daily from now as well as taking his antibiotics and being nebulised several times a day.However, Jen says that studies have shown that children with CF who take Orkambi from the age of six can live with the condition for an extra  years.ldquoThis is not just a Christmas present for this year, but for all the extra years we hope to have with Lorcaacuten, said Jen.ldquoWhilst I love Lorcaacuten to the bottom of my heart, these past three years have been very dficult. With every infection, my heart has broken a little more.ldquoNow the future is so bright for people with Cystic Fibrosis, so much brighter than I could have ever imagined when we received his diagnosis..prettyPhoto

title: Sunken fishing trawler in Scotland for inspection
story: A FISHING trawler which ran aground and sank off Ardglass harbour has arrived in Scotland for inspection after being raised from the seabed.Specialist lting gear was used to raise the Dillon Owen five weeks after it ran aground on rocks near the entrance to the villagersquos harbour on October .The carefully planned lting operation got underway on December , with the process involving engineers fitting two large strops underneath the Dillon Owen before it was hoisted clear of the water by a crane in less than two hours.Weighing  tonnes, nearly  metres long and eight metres wide, the trawler was winched on to a barge before being taken away. An investigation into the sinking of the vessel is due to be carried out by the Irish maritime organisation, the Marine Casualty Investigation Board.The trawler got into dficulty as it headed towards Ardglass harbour, with a rescue operation mounted by Newcastle and Portaferry RNLI volunteer crews who responded to a Mayday call in the early hours.The local crews worked alongside Irish Coastguardrsquos Rescue  helicopter after the call for help was made at .am.The boat got into dficulty as it tried to dock to offload its catch in poor weather. It was listing badly and had started to take on water when the leboats arrived and helped the five crew members to safety with the assistance of the Coastguard.While the vessel did not sink the day after it ran aground, it subsequently succumbed to the water a few days later due to further bad weather.The Cork-registered vessel was badly damaged and its catch was lost. Bad weather hampered attempts to lt the vessel before it was eventually hauled out of the water just over two weeks ago..prettyPhoto

title: We wanted this to be our best result and we’ve done that
story: SUCCESS in the European and local government elections has provided a springboard for a potential South Down Assembly seat for Alliance, according to Patrick Brown.He could not hide his delight after increasing the party vote across the constituency by over  percent and believed that at one stage he could potentially pip the DUPrsquos Glyn Hanna for third place.In the end, the margin between the two men was just  votes, with Mr Brown having to be content with fourth spot.He said the partyrsquos ldquopositive, progressive and pro-european message resonated with voters, suggesting that the Brexit issue not only helped him, but his colleagues across all other Westminster constituencies.He said Alliance has been consistently strong on what he described as its ldquopro-european, multi-national and international outlook, claiming that ldquopeople of all ages are sick and tired of the politics of the DUP and Sinn Fein.He believes that the only way to unite people in South Down is toa cross-community candidate to Westminster, suggesting that a number of people who voted Sinn Fein in  had backed his party this time around as they were ldquofed up with the current situation at Stormont and republicansrsquo abstentionist policy.Looking to the future, Mr Brown believes that Alliance is edging towards possibly securing a South Down Assembly seat.He continued: ldquoThe party has established a very strong foundation in the constituency and is pretty close to an Assembly quotanot just over it, based on  figures. If and when an Assembly election happens, we will certainly be putting a lot of effort into securing a seat in South Down.Mr Brown said he went into the election with the intention of building on the partyrsquos best ever performance in a Westminster poll two years ago when it secured , votes.ldquoWe wanted this election to be our best ever result and we have done that, he declared.ldquoI would say that we knocked more doors in  than in this election as I was responsible for the partyrsquos social media and digital marketing campaign. As a result, my time was split between South Down and helping out in other areas including North Down and East Belfast.ldquoI know that working full time on an election campaign in South Down we can achieve an even better result. I also know that a lot of our voters did vote tactically and respect their decision to do so. Some of my friends voted SDLP this time which wonrsquot happen in an Assembly election.Mr Brown said many would have suggested that Alliance hit its electoral ceiling in  and firmly believes there is much more to come from his party locally. He said hisof , votes is not the ceiling and that in a next election, Alliance should be be aiming to hit the , mark in South Down.Mr Brown added: ldquoThe only way is up. The election results across Northern Ireland are a complete game changer. The DUP has completely lost any influence it had at Westminster and also lost two of its key seats in Belfast and just managing to hang on to another..prettyPhoto

title: line up of calves win over judges at calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. My dad and my godfather had been out for a drink to celebrate and they came back home and my dad said to me, ‘What about you wee Gabby’ and my ma said ‘That’s it, he’s being called after you’ - my da is called David.’’Many hold the view that Christmas could well be the most advantageous day on which to be born, asit comes with a guaranteed jollity, lots of feasting and a party atmosphere.But, of course, it could also be used by Scrooge-like loved ones as an excuse to halve your annual allowance of presents.Most of us enjoy being the centre of attention on our birthday, but those born on Christmas Day may struggle for the limelight.Instead of being the most wonderful, sparkly, tinsel-filled day ever, both celebrations may be diluted. It couldalso be a tad lonely - December  is the rarest birthday , despite being perhaps the world’s most famous day.Given its rarity, it is most unusual then to discover that the two most exciting days of the calendar year fall together for two brothers - who are not twins. David Murphy and his brother Noel were both born on Christmas Day, exactly six years apart. Noel, who was born in  and lives in Dungannon, said he felt a ‘wee bit annoyed’ that he wasn’t born on a dferent date. ‘‘Obviously you miss out on a birthday present and a birthday party because I got the both of them as Christmas. ‘‘Then as I got a bit older I realised that there was a fair good chance that I was going to be off school on my birthday and off work, so that evened it out a bit. title: k pay gap vale glamorgans top bottom earners
story: The Equality Trust says figures from the Office for National Statistics, which reveal a gap of nearly pound, between the UKs highest and lowest earners, "paint a depressing picture of dangerous income inequality".In the Vale of Glamorgan, the average weekly pay packet for the top  per cent of earners in full-time roles is now . times those in the bottom fth ndash a gap of pound,.More News:Charity Christmas cards designed for Tabernacle foodbank unveiledNew poundm Five Mile Lane upgrade floods just weeks after openingPenarths RNLI crew on the hunt for new membersThe figures, for workers who live in the area, use median, rather than mean, averages, to stop them being skewed by particularly small or large salaries.They show the top  per cent of earners were paid pound weekly on average, or pound, annually.For low earners, weekly pay was just pound ndash pound, a year.The average full-time employee in the Vale of Glamorgan works . hours per week, with a median annual salary of pound,.The figures refer to basic pay and do not include bonuses or overtime.The pay gap between the Vale of Glamorgans highest and lowest earners is slightly larger than the UK average.Across the UK, the average annual salary for the top % of earners is . times as high than the lowest earners.Top earners are paid pound, on average, compared to pound, for their lowest-paid counterparts.London had the greatest gap, where top-paid earners took home pound, ndash nearly pound, more than low earners.Most equal was Wales, where the highest  per cent of earners were paid . times that of the lowest fth.Dr Wanda Wyporska, executive director of charity the Equality Trust, said: "Just like the gender pay gap, the gap between high and low paid workers is not shrinking fast enough."But this is an even greater scandal because the evidence shows that in countries with high levels of inequality, like the UK, there are higher levels of violent crime, physical and mental ill-health, infant mortality and lower levels of trust and educational attainment."By continuing to ignore inequality, decision makers are failing to truly realise the social and economic potential of this country."The Trades Union Congress estimates one in nine UK workers are in insecure and poorly paid "precarious work", including those on zero-hours contracts and self-employed people making less than the minimum wage.General secretary Frances OGrady said: "Working people deserve a fairer share of the wealth they create. Its not right that millions are struggling to make ends meet, while those at the top pocket bumper pay cheques."We need to reset the balance of power in our economy."That means giving workers new rights so they can access the protection of a union in every workplace and bargain for better pay and conditions across industries." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: bears head flushes away competition
story: The Bears Head in Windsor Road has been awarded a platinum rating by inspectors in the Loo of the Year Awards .The awards are aimed at highlighting and improving standards of away from home toilet provision across the UK.Loo of the Year Awards inspectors make unannounced visits to thousands of toilets at sites across the UK, in order to judge them.All of the toilets are graded silver, gold, platinum or diamond with unacceptable toilets not graded at all.The toilets are judged against numerous criteria, including deacutecor and maintenance, cleanliness, accessibility, hand washing and drying equipment and overall management.The Bears Head, a Wetherspoon pub, is managed by Nick Newport.Mr Newport said: "We are delighted with the award."Staff at the pub ensure the toilets are in first-class condition at all times and it is great that this has been recognised by the inspectors."The Loo of the Year Awards managing director, Mike Bone, said: "The toilets at The Bears Head have been designed and fitted out to a very high standard and are both clean and well maintained."The pub richly deserves its platinum award." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice.
